child.pub-comments: Population: 900 (2011 SIL estimate). Ethnologue notes that the use of this language is vigorous- that it is spoken widely by speakers of all ages, and that most people have positive attitudes towards the language. In some areas near Nayarit, on the other hand, the language has fallen into disuse due to the presence of a larger language group. Closest Nahuatl variant is Eastern Durango Nahuatl (85% intelligibility).
child.geography: Durango, Mezquital, San Agustin de Buenaventura, Curachitos de Buenavista, San Diego, Tepetates II, Berenjenas, Alacranes, Tepalcates, Nayarit, Acaponeta, Santa Crus, La Laguna, Mesa de las Arpas, El Duraznito
child.alt-names: Meshikan del occidente, Mexicanero del occidenta, Nahuat del Occidente en Durango y Nayarit, Western Durango Aztec
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 30,000 (2000 INALI), with 10,000 monolinguals. Ethnologue writes that children still acquire the language in rural areas, and some Spanish speaking workers speak Tarahumara for work or trade. There is a generally positive attitude towards the language, and it is spoken by multiple ages in all domains. Ethnologue goes on to say that 45,000 also use some Spanish. (Ethnologue 2013) Kaufman (2007: 54) lists this as a dialect of Tarahumara rather than a language.
child.geography: Southwest Chihuahua, from Cuautemoc, southwest to Creel down Urique river, east up Sinforosa canyon, southeast to Chinantu, north to Balleza
child.alt-names: Alta Tarahumara, Ralámuli de la Tarahumara Alta, Samachique, Tarahumara, Tarahumara de Cumbres, Tarahumara del Centro, Samachique

child.pub-comments: Population: 32,900 (2000 INALI), with 120 monolinguals. (Ethnologue 2013) Kaufman (2007:54) lists the population as a much different 16,400. Ethnologue notes that the government offers scholarships to young people who demonstrate Mayo proficiency. Primarily older adults speak this language, and the overall attitude towards it is neutral to negative. (Ethnologue 2013)
child.geography: South Sonora coast, Navojoa (Huatabampo) Area; north Sinaloa (Los Mochis, Guasave, San José Ríos, north of Guamuchil); spoken in 100+ villages

child.pub-comments: Kaufman (2007) presents this as an extinct dialect of the Kahita language, a family-level language within his Sonorran family.
child.publications: Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 54. London, New York: Routledge.

child.pub-comments: Population: 56,400 (Kaufman 2007: 54). Ethnologue writes that all ages speak this language, though some also use English. (Ethnologue 2013). Kaufman (2007) considers this to be a dialect of 'Kahita' rather than an independent language. Mithun writes that older speakers are fluent in the language, but younger speakers are bilingual or have switched to English. (Mithun 1999: 25)
child.geography: Lower Yaqui River, Southern Sonora
